comment_text.dn9:1.3: Poṭṭhapāda appears only here; he was named for a month of the lunar calendar (August/September). | Mallikā was the chief queen of Pasenadi, and her hall is mentioned in a similar context at MN 78:1.3. The commentary explains that the brahmins, Jains, and others would assemble there to “debate their beliefs” (samayaṁ pavadanti). Evidently the monastery grounds had accommodation for many ascetics of different beliefs, but only “one hall” where they would gather for debate. We hear many times of such debates, but here we catch a glimpse of a place that was set up to facilitate them. For -ācīra, read in the sense of “boundary, hedge” (commentary: timbarūrukkhapantiyā parikkhittattā; cf. Sanskrit prācīra, “enclosure, hedge, fence, wall”).
comment_text.dn9:2.2: According to the commentary, when he approached the vicinity of the city gate, he decided to check the position of the sun and noticed that it was too early to enter. The commentary and sub-commentary explain that it only sounds like the Buddha was in doubt, for Buddhas deliberate before deciding on a course of action.
comment_text.dn9:2.3: This can be understood as answering the criticism voiced in DN 8:22.2, that the Buddha was afraid to speak in an assembly.
comment_text.dn9:3.1: In contrast with the silence of the Buddha’s community at DN 2:10.7.
comment_text.dn9:4.6: The Buddha encourages quiet for the sake of mental development; Poṭṭhapāda does it for the sake of reputation.
comment_text.dn9:5.3: Poṭṭhapāda’s address is almost overly deferential.
comment_text.dn9:5.10: Always polite, the Buddha begins by showing an interest in them.
comment_text.dn9:6.4: Abhisaññā does not appear elsewhere. Here the prefix abhi- means not “higher”, but rather “about, concerning”. Compare abhidhamma at MN 32:8.6: dve bhikkhū abhidhammakathaṁ kathenti (“two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching”); also abhivinaya at AN 3.140:4.4. The commentary here says abhi- is a mere particle, so it need not be translated.
comment_text.dn9:6.5: This discussion appears to have been directly sparked by the difficult passage in Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12 and 4.5.13. The sage Yājñavalkya, teaching his wife Maitreyī, says that the true Self is a sheer mass of “consciousness” (vijñāna, Pali viññāṇa), which is “great, endless, infinite reality”. After realizing this, he says, there is no “perception” (saṁjñā, Pali saññā), a statement that bewilders even the wise Maitreyī. He explains that only in an apparent state of duality (dvaitamiva) do the separate functions of sense consciousness operate. When all is realized as the Self, how, he asks, can one know that owing to which all this is known? He is implicitly distinguishing between viññāna as “infinite” (= vi-) knowing and saññā as “constrained” (saṁ-) knowing. Yājñavalkya says the separate Self emerges with these elements and vanishes with them (etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānu vinaśyati), but he does not explain how or why this happens, which is the question the theorists here attempt to address.
comment_text.dn9:6.7: Here perception is not identified with the “person” (purisa), but rather belongs to them (cf. etaṁ mama, “this is mine”). In the discussion to follow, the Buddha only directly addresses this theory, while the remainder are included by inference.
comment_text.dn9:6.13: The self is defined as perception (eso me attā), one of the five aggregates. Compare the various theories of the self and perception at DN 1:2.38.0.
comment_text.dn9:6.16: Implying that at such times a person lacks a “self”. This is perhaps related to Yājñavalkya’s: “That man, when born, acquiring a body, is connected with ills (the bodily organs); and when he dies, departing, he discards those ills” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.8).
comment_text.dn9:6.20: The commentary says these were devotees of āthabbaṇa, i.e the practices preserved in the Atharvaveda. This “fourth Veda” is mentioned only once by name in the early Pali (Snp 4.14:13.1), where, as here, it is associated with the performance of magic and the casting of spells. The commentary fairly drips with contempt: “Allegedly, the Āthabbaṇa practitioners cast a spell, showing a creature’s head as if cut off, or their hand as if cut off, or as if dead. Then they show them back to normal; imagining so, they say, ‘From cessation they have arisen.’”
comment_text.dn9:6.21: See DN 29:16.20 for upakaḍḍhati and apakaḍḍhati in this sense.
comment_text.dn9:6.34: Pakataññū is not elsewhere attested in the suttas, but it is found in the Vinaya, for example at Bu Pc 72:1.8).
comment_text.dn9:7.5: Here the Buddha argues that, since it is possible to change the nature of one’s own mind through practice, such changes cannot be random.
comment_text.dn9:7.6: It is is unusual if not unique to add “said the Buddha” (bhagavā avoca) in such a context. Normally, once a speaker starts, the text does not insert extra tags identifying the speaker without a reason, such as an interruption for a question.
comment_text.dn9:7.8: Sinhalese manuscripts, followed by PTS, include the paragraphs on the metaphor of the king’s security (DN 2:63.1) and on guarding the sense doors here.
comment_text.dn9:10.2: Progress through the jhānas is explained in terms of the refining of perceptions.
comment_text.dn9:10.3: “Subtle and true” is sukhumasacca, a term that appears only here.
comment_text.dn9:14.1: We have encountered the “formless attainments” (arūpasamāpatti) before, where they formed a refined basis for attachment to self (DN 1:3.13.4). Here they appear as part of the gradual refinement of consciousness through the cessation of increasingly subtle perceptions.
comment_text.dn9:14.2: This is the vision of light that later came to be called a “sign” (nimitta). In the first four jhānas this persists as a “subtle” (sukhuma) reflection or echo of the “substantial” (olārika) material basis of meditation, such as the breath or the parts of the body. Even though it is a purely mental phenomenon, it is still “form” (rūpa) since it has physical properties like light or extension.
comment_text.dn9:14.3: The “light” (obhāsa) of jhāna grows from “limited” (paritta) to “limitless” (appamāṇa, MN 128:29.1). Then the perception of even this limitless light vanishes, leaving only infinite space.
comment_text.dn9:15.1: Perception of infinite space fades away leaving only the infinite consciousness that is aware.
comment_text.dn9:16.1: The meditator is no longer even aware of infinite consciousness, but of the even vaster nothingness.
comment_text.dn9:16.4: The last of the four formless attainments is the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. Since this, by definition, lies beyond the scope of perception, it is not included here.
comment_text.dn9:17.1: For sakasaññī (“takes charge of their own perception”), see Bu Pj 2:6.2.2. One relevant factor in determining whether an object has been stolen is if the accused “perceives it as their own”. Here it means that the meditator understands that they can evolve their own perceptions through meditation.
comment_text.dn9:17.4: “Intend and choose” is ceteyyaṁ abhisaṅkhareyyaṁ (1st singular optative). These synonyms are used in the sense of a subtle sense of will or intentionality that underlies such attainments (MN 52:14.3) and which must be let go lest they generate rebirth (MN 140:22.10).
comment_text.dn9:17.9: Compare with “progressive cessation” (AN 9.31), “progressive tranquilizing of conditions” (SN 36.15), “progressive meditations” (AN 9.32), etc. | “Awareness” is sampajāna, which we have encountered previously as “situational awareness” in daily activities, or as the “awareness” in the third jhāna. Here it refers to a reflective capacity to understand the nature of deep meditation in terms of causality. The term was adopted by Patañjalī, who defined saṁprajñātasamādhi in a way that is clearly drawn from the Buddhist definition of jhāna. It is attained with vitakka, vicāra, ānanda (“bliss”), and āsmitā. According to the commentary, this last term is “experience of the one self”, ekātmikā saṁvid) and so is probably adapted from the Buddhist factor of ekaggatā. (Yogasūtra 1.17).
comment_text.dn9:18.3: Taking the kernel of Yājñavalkya’s theory of the cessation of limited perception, the Buddha has expanded it in psychological and practical detail, while leaving out the metaphysical assumption of the Self.
comment_text.dn9:18.4: Poṭṭhapāda shows the Buddha that he has been paying attention. Notice how it is culturally assumed that it is possible to retain and repeat the exact content of the teaching.
comment_text.dn9:19.4: The meaning of this is not clear to me. It might mean that insight can be developed based on any of the stages of meditation, so for that person their peak of perception is different to another’s. The commentary says that it refers to different meditation subjects, or simply to different occasions of meditation.
comment_text.dn9:20.1: Poṭṭhapāda’s distinction between “perception” (saññā) and “knowledge” (ñāṇa) echoes Yājñavalkya’s distinction between “perception” (saṁjā) and “consciousness” (vijñāna, or in the repeated passage at 4.5.13, prajñāna).
comment_text.dn9:20.2: Perception has been described in terms of the progress through more refined meditations (samādhi). Only then does the “knowledge” (ñāṇa) of insight arise.
comment_text.dn9:20.4: The term “specific condition” (idappaccayā) is well known from dependent origination (eg. SN 12.20:2.3), where it applies to the general situation of ongoing existence in transmigration. When developing insight, a meditator takes their own meditation experience as their primary locus. This is then generalized to an understanding of the nature of conscious existence.
comment_text.dn9:21.1: This draws from the initial presentation of different theories of the person and perception (DN 9:6.4).
comment_text.dn9:21.2: “Believe” is paccesi, literally “fall back on”. It implies that an idea is something one relies on or takes as fundamental. The Buddha wants to know where Poṭṭhapāda stands before exploring this topic.
comment_text.dn9:21.3: Despite his previous questions about perception and the self, Poṭṭhapāda takes his stand on a purely materialist view, identifying the “self” with the organic “substantial” body.
comment_text.dn9:21.4: Again, the Buddha does not rush to tell Poṭṭhapāda he is right or wrong, but rather draws out the implications of his statement.
comment_text.dn9:21.6: Here tiṭṭhateva is not “leaving aside”, but “remains”. Compare the similar construction at MN 107:13.1.
comment_text.dn9:22.1: This is the “subtle” (sukhuma) body, corresponding with the form experienced in the four jhānas. All manuscripts appear to be missing the expected rūpī in this passage, but it occurs in the corresponding passage on “reincarnation” below.
comment_text.dn9:23.1: This identifies the self as that which is experienced in the formless attainments. Poṭṭhapāda is simply cycling through possible self theories without really thinking through the implications.
comment_text.dn9:24.1: Poṭṭhapāda can only attest a belief in various theories and still does not know how to assess them for himself.
comment_text.dn9:24.3: The text shifts from añña “other” (eg. aññadiṭṭhikena) to aññatra (aññatr’āyogena), which normally means “apart from”. Most authorities follow the commentary in taking aññatra here in the sense of “other”. However I think the change of sense is deliberate; the Buddha is not discouraging them, merely informing them what it will take.
comment_text.dn9:25.3: This is the famous list of ten “undeclared points”, which are found throughout the suttas (eg. MN 25:10.21, MN 63:2.3, MN 72:3.1, and the whole of SN 44). They seem to have functioned as a kind of checklist by which philosophers could be evaluated and classified. | The word loka occurs in a number of senses, but here it refers to the entire “cosmos” of countless worlds.
comment_text.dn9:31.1: This phrase recurs at SN 21.9:1.4 and AN 3.64:11.1, with some variant readings.
comment_text.dn9:32.1: The commentary says Citta was the son of an elephant trainer. Here he shows greater respect to the Buddha than does Poṭṭhapāda.
comment_text.dn9:33.3: This point seems to be lost on a number of modern commentators, who infer from passages such as the ten undeclared points that the Buddha refused to make any definitive declarations at all. The Buddha, rather, was a vibhajjavādin (MN 99:4.4, AN 10.94:4.7), “one who speaks after analysis”.
comment_text.dn9:34.4: The Buddha does not rely on rumor; he begins by checking his facts with those concerned. Not only does this affirm his commitment to truth, it shows respect and establishes a common ground from which the argument proceeds.
comment_text.dn9:34.8: The verb viharati means “dwell”, and functions as an auxiliary verb implying duration. In spiritual contexts it often means “a period or state of meditation”. This first question is asking whether they see such a state in a regular meditation practice.
comment_text.dn9:34.11: Perhaps they might not be able to develop a meditation for seeing that self, but at some point they may have had some sort of perception or vision or insight.
comment_text.dn9:34.15: Since they have no experience, they might at least have an idea how to reach that experience.
comment_text.dn9:34.19: They haven’t even heard a report about it.
comment_text.dn9:34.23: “No demonstrable basis” renders appāṭihīrakataṁ. The Vedic pratiharate means “to yearn for, to welcome, to delight in”, from which pāṭihāriya means “that which should be delighted in, an amusement, an entertainment, an attraction”. In early Pali, the primary sense is something demonstrated or displayed that is convincing or inspiring. In later Pali this narrows to “miracle”.
comment_text.dn9:35.2: Janapadakalyāṇī is typically rendered as “the most beautiful lady in the land”. At SN 47.20:2.2 we learn that she is a dazzling singer and dancer. And while she was famed for her beauty (Ud 3.2:9.1), the word kalyāṇa normally means “(morally) good, fine, lovely” and does not refer solely to her appearance.
comment_text.dn9:35.7: The same color “dingy”—mud-green—is used of Gotama when his skin was ruined by austerities. It might seem an odd color for a beautiful woman, but then “men’s tastes vary” (SN 4.25:5.2).
comment_text.dn9:37.1: Nisseni only occurs elsewhere in Bu Ss 6:2.3.6 and Bu Ss 7:2.67, where it is something carried, i.e. a ladder rather than a flight of stairs.
comment_text.dn9:39.1: Attapaṭilābha is literally “re-acquisition of self”, where attā is explained by the commentary as attabhāva, the “state of the self” or “life-form” that is acquired at rebirth, i.e. the body (sarīra), whether material or immaterial.Here we see an echo of the old use of ātman as “body”, although it is applied even to the formless realms.
comment_text.dn9:39.2: These recap the three theses of perception and the self posted by Poṭṭhapāda from DN 9:22.1.
comment_text.dn9:40.4: Compare with the similar sentiment at SN 22.2:10.1.
comment_text.dn9:44.4: The Buddha points to the experience to demonstrate what he is talking about, rather than offering a long theoretical explanation. Ayaṁ is a pronoun of presence, used to indicate what is apparent before the subject.
comment_text.dn9:48.2: Citta is asking an ontological question, assuming that these three states are existent realities of the self.
comment_text.dn9:49.1: The Buddha reframes the question as one of conventional description. He is describing states in which one might be reborn, not underlying ontologies.
comment_text.dn9:49.8: This anticipates one of the great philosophical debates of sectarian Buddhists which gave rise to the Sarvāstivāda, the school whose core doctrine was that “all exists (in the past, future, and present)”. The Buddha describes past, future, and present with the three grammatical tenses.
comment_text.dn9:53.5: Words such as “self” have a conventional usage and in that context are perfectly fine. But what that “self” refers to is constantly changing, as it is reincarnated in different states. It is like a river which keeps the same name even though the water is always changing. If, driven by attachment, we assume there is a metaphysical reality underlying the conventional “self”, we step beyond what can be empirically verified. Note, however, that the Buddha is not asserting that there are two levels of truth, conventional and ultimate, a distinction not found in early Buddhism. | Compare MN 139:3.9, MN 74:13.1, SN 1.25.
comment_text.dn9:56.2: In AN 6.60 we find Citta Hatthisāriputta, still a somewhat junior monk, rudely interrupting his seniors. After admonition he disrobed, but he ordained again and later achieved arahantship. We can reconcile these two accounts by recognizing that the phrase acira “not long after” is a conventional term, which might be several years. Thus the events of AN 6.60 occurred some time between his ordination and awakening.

root_text.dn9:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.dn9:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako samayappavādake tindukācīre ekasālake mallikāya ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ tiṁsamattehi paribbājakasatehi.
root_text.dn9:1.4: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.dn9:2.3: Yannūnāhaṁ yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo, yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
root_text.dn9:2.4: Atha kho bhagavā yena samayappavādako tindukācīro ekasālako mallikāya ārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.dn9:3.1: Tena kho pana samayena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentiyā.
root_text.dn9:3.2: Seyyathidaṁ—rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ mahāmattakathaṁ senākathaṁ bhayakathaṁ yuddhakathaṁ annakathaṁ pānakathaṁ vatthakathaṁ sayanakathaṁ mālākathaṁ gandhakathaṁ ñātikathaṁ yānakathaṁ gāmakathaṁ nigamakathaṁ nagarakathaṁ janapadakathaṁ itthikathaṁ sūrakathaṁ visikhākathaṁ kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṁ pubbapetakathaṁ nānattakathaṁ lokakkhāyikaṁ samuddakkhāyikaṁ itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
root_text.dn9:4.1: Addasā kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ;
root_text.dn9:4.5: Appasaddakāmo kho so āyasmā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī.
root_text.dn9:4.6: Appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
root_text.dn9:4.7: Evaṁ vutte, te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn9:5.1: Atha kho bhagavā yena poṭṭhapādo paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.dn9:5.2: Atha kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:5.5: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
root_text.dn9:5.6: Nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā, idaṁ āsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
root_text.dn9:5.8: Poṭṭhapādopi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn9:5.9: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho poṭṭhapādaṁ paribbājakaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:5.10: “kāya nuttha, poṭṭhapāda, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
root_text.dn9:6.1: Evaṁ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:6.2: “tiṭṭhatesā, bhante, kathā, yāya mayaṁ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā.
root_text.dn9:6.3: Nesā, bhante, kathā bhagavato dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya.
root_text.dn9:6.4: Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni, nānātitthiyānaṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ kotūhalasālāya sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ abhisaññānirodhe kathā udapādi:
root_text.dn9:6.8: Yasmiṁ samaye uppajjanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:6.9: Yasmiṁ samaye nirujjhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
root_text.dn9:6.12: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
root_text.dn9:6.15: Yasmiṁ samaye upeti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:6.16: Yasmiṁ samaye apeti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
root_text.dn9:6.19: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
root_text.dn9:6.20: Santi hi, bho, samaṇabrāhmaṇā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā.
root_text.dn9:6.21: Te imassa purisassa saññaṁ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi.
root_text.dn9:6.22: Yasmiṁ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:6.23: Yasmiṁ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
root_text.dn9:6.26: ‘na kho pana metaṁ, bho, evaṁ bhavissati.
root_text.dn9:6.27: Santi hi, bho, devatā mahiddhikā mahānubhāvā.
root_text.dn9:6.28: Tā imassa purisassa saññaṁ upakaḍḍhantipi apakaḍḍhantipi.
root_text.dn9:6.29: Yasmiṁ samaye upakaḍḍhanti, saññī tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:6.30: Yasmiṁ samaye apakaḍḍhanti, asaññī tasmiṁ samaye hotī’ti.
root_text.dn9:6.32: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva ārabbha sati udapādi:
root_text.dn9:6.33: ‘aho nūna bhagavā, aho nūna sugato, yo imesaṁ dhammānaṁ sukusalo’ti.
root_text.dn9:6.34: Bhagavā, bhante, kusalo, bhagavā pakataññū abhisaññānirodhassa.
root_text.dn9:6.35: Kathaṁ nu kho, bhante, abhisaññānirodho hotī”ti?
root_text.dn9:7.2: ‘ahetū appaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipī’ti, āditova tesaṁ aparaddhaṁ.
root_text.dn9:7.4: Sahetū hi, poṭṭhapāda, sappaccayā purisassa saññā uppajjantipi nirujjhantipi.
root_text.dn9:7.5: Sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:7.7: “Idha, poṭṭhapāda, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ, sammāsambuddho …pe…
root_text.dn9:7.8: Evaṁ kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sīlasampanno hoti
root_text.dn9:9.1: tassime pañcanīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
root_text.dn9:10.1: So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:10.2: Tassa yā purimā kāmasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:10.3: Vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:10.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:11.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:11.2: Tassa yā purimā vivekajapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:11.3: Samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:11.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:12.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:12.2: Tassa yā purimā samādhijapītisukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:12.3: Upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:12.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:13.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:13.2: Tassa yā purimā upekkhāsukhasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:13.3: Adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, adukkhamasukhasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:13.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:14.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:14.2: Tassa yā purimā rūpasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:14.3: Ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:14.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:15.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:15.2: Tassa yā purimā ākāsānañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:15.3: Viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:15.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:16.1: “Puna caparaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.dn9:16.2: Tassa yā purimā viññāṇañcāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā, sā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:16.3: Ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññā tasmiṁ samaye hoti, ākiñcaññāyatanasukhumasaccasaññīyeva tasmiṁ samaye hoti.
root_text.dn9:16.4: Evampi sikkhā ekā saññā uppajjati, sikkhā ekā saññā nirujjhati.
root_text.dn9:17.1: “Yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṁ phusati.
root_text.dn9:17.4: Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṁ, abhisaṅkhareyyaṁ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṁ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṁ;
root_text.dn9:17.5: yannūnāhaṁ na ceva ceteyyaṁ na ca abhisaṅkhareyyan’ti.
root_text.dn9:17.6: So na ceva ceteti, na ca abhisaṅkharoti.
root_text.dn9:17.7: Tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti.
root_text.dn9:18.2: api nu te ito pubbe evarūpā anupubbābhisaññānirodhasampajānasamāpatti sutapubbā”ti?
root_text.dn9:18.4: Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, bhagavato bhāsitaṁ ājānāmi:
root_text.dn9:18.5: ‘yato kho, poṭṭhapāda, bhikkhu idha sakasaññī hoti, so tato amutra tato amutra anupubbena saññaggaṁ phusati,
root_text.dn9:18.8: Ahañceva kho pana ceteyyaṁ abhisaṅkhareyyaṁ, imā ca me saññā nirujjheyyuṁ, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā uppajjeyyuṁ;
root_text.dn9:18.9: yannūnāhaṁ na ceva ceteyyaṁ, na ca abhisaṅkhareyyan”ti.
root_text.dn9:18.10: So na ceva ceteti, na cābhisaṅkharoti, tassa acetayato anabhisaṅkharoto tā ceva saññā nirujjhanti, aññā ca oḷārikā saññā na uppajjanti.
root_text.dn9:19.1: “Ekaññeva nu kho, bhante, bhagavā saññaggaṁ paññapeti, udāhu puthūpi saññagge paññapetī”ti?
root_text.dn9:19.2: “Ekampi kho ahaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, saññaggaṁ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī”ti.
root_text.dn9:19.3: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bhante, bhagavā ekampi saññaggaṁ paññapeti, puthūpi saññagge paññapetī”ti?
root_text.dn9:19.4: “Yathā yathā kho, poṭṭhapāda, nirodhaṁ phusati tathā tathāhaṁ saññaggaṁ paññapemi.
root_text.dn9:19.5: Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, ekampi saññaggaṁ paññapemi, puthūpi saññagge paññapemī”ti.
root_text.dn9:20.1: “Saññā nu kho, bhante, paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, udāhu ñāṇaṁ paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā saññā, udāhu saññā ca ñāṇañca apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjantī”ti?
root_text.dn9:20.2: “Saññā kho, poṭṭhapāda, paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hoti.
root_text.dn9:20.5: Iminā kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ—
root_text.dn9:20.6: yathā saññā paṭhamaṁ uppajjati, pacchā ñāṇaṁ, saññuppādā ca pana ñāṇuppādo hotī”ti.
root_text.dn9:21.1: “Saññā nu kho, bhante, purisassa attā, udāhu aññā saññā añño attā”ti?
root_text.dn9:21.3: “Oḷārikaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, attānaṁ paccemi rūpiṁ cātumahābhūtikaṁ kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhan”ti.
root_text.dn9:21.4: “Oḷāriko ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho. Evaṁ santaṁ kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:21.5: Tadamināpetaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:21.6: Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, oḷāriko attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkho, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti.
root_text.dn9:21.7: Iminā kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā”ti.
root_text.dn9:22.1: “Manomayaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, attānaṁ paccemi sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṁ ahīnindriyan”ti.
root_text.dn9:22.2: “Manomayo ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo, evaṁ santampi kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:22.3: Tadamināpetaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:22.4: Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, manomayo attā sabbaṅgapaccaṅgī ahīnindriyo, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti.
root_text.dn9:22.5: Imināpi kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā”ti.
root_text.dn9:23.1: “Arūpiṁ kho ahaṁ, bhante, attānaṁ paccemi saññāmayan”ti.
root_text.dn9:23.2: “Arūpī ca hi te, poṭṭhapāda, attā abhavissa saññāmayo, evaṁ santampi kho te, poṭṭhapāda, aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:23.3: Tadamināpetaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā.
root_text.dn9:23.4: Tiṭṭhateva sāyaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, arūpī attā saññāmayo, atha imassa purisassa aññā ca saññā uppajjanti, aññā ca saññā nirujjhanti.
root_text.dn9:23.5: Imināpi kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā aññāva saññā bhavissati añño attā”ti.
root_text.dn9:24.2: ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā ‘aññāva saññā añño attā’ti vā”ti?
root_text.dn9:24.3: “Dujjānaṁ kho etaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena:
root_text.dn9:24.4: ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā, ‘aññāva saññā añño attāti’ vā”ti.
root_text.dn9:25.1: “Sacetaṁ, bhante, mayā dujjānaṁ aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrāyogena aññatrācariyakena:
root_text.dn9:25.2: ‘saññā purisassa attā’ti vā, ‘aññāva saññā añño attā’ti vā;
root_text.dn9:25.3: kiṁ pana, bhante, ‘sassato loko, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’”ti?
root_text.dn9:26.1: “Kiṁ pana, bhante, ‘asassato loko, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’”ti?
root_text.dn9:27.7: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā …
root_text.dn9:27.8: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’”ti?
root_text.dn9:27.10: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā, idameva saccaṁ moghamaññan’”ti.
root_text.dn9:28.2: “Na hetaṁ, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṁhitaṁ na dhammasaṁhitaṁ nādibrahmacariyakaṁ, na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati,
root_text.dn9:29.2: “Idaṁ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākataṁ. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā byākatan”ti.
root_text.dn9:30.2: “Etañhi, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṁhitaṁ, etaṁ dhammasaṁhitaṁ, etaṁ ādibrahmacariyakaṁ, etaṁ nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati;
root_text.dn9:31.1: Atha kho te paribbājakā acirapakkantassa bhagavato poṭṭhapādaṁ paribbājakaṁ samantato vācā sannitodakena sañjhabbharimakaṁsu:
root_text.dn9:31.2: “evameva panāyaṁ bhavaṁ poṭṭhapādo yaññadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsati, taṁ tadevassa abbhanumodati:
root_text.dn9:31.4: Na kho pana mayaṁ kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṁsikaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāma:
root_text.dn9:31.5: ‘sassato loko’ti vā, ‘asassato loko’ti vā, ‘antavā loko’ti vā, ‘anantavā loko’ti vā, ‘taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran’ti vā, ‘aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran’ti vā, ‘hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā”ti.
root_text.dn9:31.6: Evaṁ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako te paribbājake etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:31.7: “ahampi kho, bho, na kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṁsikaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
root_text.dn9:31.9: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti vā;
root_text.dn9:31.10: api ca samaṇo gotamo bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ tathaṁ paṭipadaṁ paññapeti dhammaṭṭhitataṁ dhammaniyāmataṁ.
root_text.dn9:31.11: Bhūtaṁ kho pana tacchaṁ tathaṁ paṭipadaṁ paññapentassa dhammaṭṭhitataṁ dhammaniyāmataṁ, kathañhi nāma mādiso viññū samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṁ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyyā”ti?
root_text.dn9:32.1: Atha kho dvīhatīhassa accayena citto ca hatthisāriputto poṭṭhapādo ca paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā citto hatthisāriputto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn9:32.2: Poṭṭhapādo pana paribbājako bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn9:32.3: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:32.4: “tadā maṁ, bhante, te paribbājakā acirapakkantassa bhagavato samantato vācāsannitodakena sañjhabbharimakaṁsu:
root_text.dn9:32.5: ‘evameva panāyaṁ bhavaṁ poṭṭhapādo yaññadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsati, taṁ tadevassa abbhanumodati:
root_text.dn9:32.7: Na kho pana mayaṁ kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṁsikaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāma:
root_text.dn9:32.8: “sassato loko”ti vā, “asassato loko”ti vā, “antavā loko”ti vā, “anantavā loko”ti vā, “taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīran”ti vā, “aññaṁ jīvaṁ aññaṁ sarīran”ti vā, “hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā, “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā’ti.
root_text.dn9:32.9: Evaṁ vuttāhaṁ, bhante, te paribbājake etadavocaṁ:
root_text.dn9:32.10: ‘ahampi kho, bho, na kiñci samaṇassa gotamassa ekaṁsikaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
root_text.dn9:32.12: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā”ti vā;
root_text.dn9:32.13: api ca samaṇo gotamo bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ tathaṁ paṭipadaṁ paññapeti dhammaṭṭhitataṁ dhammaniyāmataṁ.
root_text.dn9:32.14: Bhūtaṁ kho pana tacchaṁ tathaṁ paṭipadaṁ paññapentassa dhammaṭṭhitataṁ dhammaniyāmataṁ, kathañhi nāma mādiso viññū samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṁ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyyā’”ti?
root_text.dn9:33.1: “Sabbeva kho ete, poṭṭhapāda, paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā;
root_text.dn9:33.3: Ekaṁsikāpi hi kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā dhammā desitā paññattā;
root_text.dn9:33.4: anekaṁsikāpi hi kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā dhammā desitā paññattā.
root_text.dn9:33.5: Katame ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā?
root_text.dn9:33.6: ‘Sassato loko’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto;
root_text.dn9:33.7: ‘asassato loko’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto;
root_text.dn9:33.13: na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda …
root_text.dn9:33.14: ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda …
root_text.dn9:33.15: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṁ maraṇā’ti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto.
root_text.dn9:33.16: Kasmā ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā anekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā?
root_text.dn9:33.17: Na hete, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṁhitā na dhammasaṁhitā na ādibrahmacariyakā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn9:33.18: Tasmā te mayā anekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā.
root_text.dn9:33.20: Katame ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā?
root_text.dn9:33.21: Idaṁ dukkhanti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto.
root_text.dn9:33.22: Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto.
root_text.dn9:33.23: Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto.
root_text.dn9:33.24: Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti kho, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsiko dhammo desito paññatto.
root_text.dn9:33.25: Kasmā ca te, poṭṭhapāda, mayā ekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā?
root_text.dn9:33.26: Ete hi, poṭṭhapāda, atthasaṁhitā, ete dhammasaṁhitā, ete ādibrahmacariyakā ete nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.dn9:33.27: Tasmā te mayā ekaṁsikā dhammā desitā paññattā.
root_text.dn9:34.1: Santi, poṭṭhapāda, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.dn9:34.6: Te ce me evaṁ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti.
root_text.dn9:34.8: ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekantasukhaṁ lokaṁ jānaṁ passaṁ viharathā’ti?
root_text.dn9:34.11: ‘api pana tumhe āyasmanto ekaṁ vā rattiṁ ekaṁ vā divasaṁ upaḍḍhaṁ vā rattiṁ upaḍḍhaṁ vā divasaṁ ekantasukhiṁ attānaṁ sañjānāthā’ti?
root_text.dn9:34.15: “ayaṁ maggo ayaṁ paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”’ti?

root_text.dn9:50.13: Yo me etarahi paccuppanno attapaṭilābho, sova me attapaṭilābho sacco, mogho atīto, mogho anāgato’ti.
root_text.dn9:50.14: Evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyan”ti.
root_text.dn9:51.1: “Evameva kho, citta, yasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na arūpo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.dn9:51.2: Oḷāriko attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.dn9:51.3: Yasmiṁ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
root_text.dn9:51.4: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.dn9:51.5: arūpo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.dn9:52.1: Seyyathāpi, citta, gavā khīraṁ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṁ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo.
root_text.dn9:52.2: Yasmiṁ samaye khīraṁ hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye dadhīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappimaṇḍoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.dn9:52.7: sappimaṇḍo hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye khīranti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na dadhīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na navanītanti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na sappīti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.dn9:53.1: Evameva kho, citta, yasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
root_text.dn9:53.2: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye manomayo attapaṭilābho hoti …pe…
root_text.dn9:53.3: yasmiṁ, citta, samaye arūpo attapaṭilābho hoti, neva tasmiṁ samaye oḷāriko attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati, na manomayo attapaṭilābhoti saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.dn9:53.4: arūpo attapaṭilābhotveva tasmiṁ samaye saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.dn9:53.5: Imā kho, citta, lokasamaññā lokaniruttiyo lokavohārā lokapaññattiyo, yāhi tathāgato voharati aparāmasan”ti.
root_text.dn9:54.1: Evaṁ vutte, poṭṭhapādo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn9:54.3: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn9:54.4: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn9:54.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.
root_text.dn9:55.3: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn9:55.4: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn9:55.5: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
root_text.dn9:56.1: Alattha kho citto hatthisāriputto bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.dn9:56.2: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.dn9:56.3: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthAttāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.dn9:56.4: Aññataro kho panāyasmā citto hatthisāriputto arahataṁ ahosīti.

translation_text.dn9:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.dn9:1.3: Now at that time the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda was residing together with three hundred wanderers in Mallikā’s single-halled monastery for philosophical debates, hedged by pale-moon ebony trees.
translation_text.dn9:1.4: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.dn9:2.2: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
translation_text.dn9:2.3: Why don’t I go to Mallikā’s monastery to visit the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda?”
translation_text.dn9:3.1: Now at that time, Poṭṭhapāda was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
translation_text.dn9:3.2: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
translation_text.dn9:4.1: Poṭṭhapāda saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
translation_text.dn9:4.3: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
translation_text.dn9:4.5: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
translation_text.dn9:4.6: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
translation_text.dn9:5.4: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
translation_text.dn9:5.5: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.dn9:5.6: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.dn9:5.7: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.dn9:5.8: while Poṭṭhapāda took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.dn9:5.10: “Poṭṭhapāda, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.dn9:6.1: When he said this, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn9:6.2: “Sir, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
translation_text.dn9:6.3: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
translation_text.dn9:6.4: Sir, a few days ago several ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions were sitting together at the debating hall, and a discussion about the cessation of perception came up among them:
translation_text.dn9:6.5: ‘How does the cessation of perception happen?’
translation_text.dn9:6.7: ‘A person’s perceptions arise and cease without cause or reason.
translation_text.dn9:6.8: When they arise, you become percipient.
translation_text.dn9:6.9: When they cease, you become non-percipient.’
translation_text.dn9:6.10: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.12: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
translation_text.dn9:6.15: When it enters, you become percipient.
translation_text.dn9:6.16: When it departs, you become non-percipient.’
translation_text.dn9:6.17: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.19: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
translation_text.dn9:6.20: There are ascetics and brahmins of great power and might.
translation_text.dn9:6.21: They insert and extract a person’s perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.22: When they insert it, you become percipient.
translation_text.dn9:6.23: When they extract it, you become non-percipient.’
translation_text.dn9:6.24: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.26: ‘That’s not how it is, good fellows!
translation_text.dn9:6.27: There are deities of great power and might.
translation_text.dn9:6.28: They insert and extract a person’s perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.29: When they insert it, you become percipient.
translation_text.dn9:6.30: When they extract it, you become non-percipient.’
translation_text.dn9:6.31: That’s how some describe the cessation of perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.32: That reminded me of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn9:6.33: ‘Surely it must be the Blessed One, the Holy One who is so very skilled in such matters.’
translation_text.dn9:6.34: The Buddha is skilled and well-versed concerning the cessation of perception.
translation_text.dn9:6.35: How does the cessation of perception happen?”
translation_text.dn9:7.1: “Regarding this, Poṭṭhapāda, those ascetics and brahmins who say that
translation_text.dn9:7.2: a person’s perceptions arise and cease without cause or reason are wrong from the start.
translation_text.dn9:7.4: Because a person’s perceptions arise and cease with cause and reason.
translation_text.dn9:7.5: With training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:7.6: And what is that training?” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:7.7: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
translation_text.dn9:7.8: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …
translation_text.dn9:9.1: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
translation_text.dn9:10.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn9:10.2: The sensual perception that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:10.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.dn9:10.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:10.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:11.1: “Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.dn9:11.2: The subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of seclusion that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:11.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.dn9:11.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:11.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:12.1: “Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.dn9:12.2: The subtle and true perception of the rapture and bliss born of immersion that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:12.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of bliss with equanimity.
translation_text.dn9:12.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:12.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:13.1: “Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.dn9:13.2: The subtle and true perception of bliss with equanimity that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:13.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of neutral feeling.
translation_text.dn9:13.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:13.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:14.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn9:14.2: The perception of luminous form that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:14.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.dn9:14.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:14.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:15.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn9:15.2: The subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite space that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:15.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness.
translation_text.dn9:15.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:15.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:16.1: “Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn9:16.2: The subtle and true perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness that they had previously ceases.
translation_text.dn9:16.3: At that time they have a subtle and true perception of the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.dn9:16.4: That’s how, with training, certain perceptions arise and certain perceptions cease.
translation_text.dn9:16.5: And this is that training,” said the Buddha.
translation_text.dn9:17.1: “Poṭṭhapāda, from the time a mendicant here takes charge of their own perception, they proceed from one stage to the next, progressively reaching the peak of perception.
translation_text.dn9:17.2: Standing on the peak of perception they think,
translation_text.dn9:17.3: ‘Intentionality is bad for me, it’s better to be free of it.
translation_text.dn9:17.4: For if I were to intend and choose, these perceptions would cease in me, and other coarser perceptions would arise.
translation_text.dn9:17.5: Why don’t I neither make a choice nor form an intention?’
translation_text.dn9:17.6: They neither make a choice nor form an intention.
translation_text.dn9:17.7: Those perceptions cease in them, and other coarser perceptions don’t arise.
translation_text.dn9:17.9: And that, Poṭṭhapāda, is how the progressive cessation of perception is attained with awareness.
translation_text.dn9:18.2: Have you ever heard of this before?”
translation_text.dn9:18.4: This is how I understand what the Buddha said:
translation_text.dn9:18.5: ‘From the time a mendicant here takes charge of their own perception, they proceed from one stage to the next, progressively reaching the peak of perception.
translation_text.dn9:18.6: Standing on the peak of perception they think,
translation_text.dn9:18.7: “Intentionality is bad for me, it’s better to be free of it.
translation_text.dn9:18.8: For if I were to intend and choose, these perceptions would cease in me, and other coarser perceptions would arise.
translation_text.dn9:18.9: Why don’t I neither make a choice nor form an intention?”
translation_text.dn9:18.10: Those perceptions cease in them, and other coarser perceptions don’t arise.
translation_text.dn9:18.12: And that is how the progressive cessation of perception is attained with awareness.’”
translation_text.dn9:19.1: “Does the Buddha describe just one peak of perception, or many?”
translation_text.dn9:19.2: “I describe the peak of perception as both one and many.”
translation_text.dn9:19.3: “But sir, how do you describe it as one peak and as many?”
translation_text.dn9:19.4: “I describe the peak of perception according to the specific manner in which one touches cessation.
translation_text.dn9:19.5: That’s how I describe the peak of perception as both one and many.”
translation_text.dn9:20.1: “But sir, does perception arise first and knowledge afterwards? Or does knowledge arise first and perception afterwards? Or do they both arise at the same time?”
translation_text.dn9:20.2: “Perception arises first and knowledge afterwards. The arising of perception leads to the arising of knowledge.
translation_text.dn9:20.4: ‘My knowledge arose from a specific condition.’
translation_text.dn9:20.5: That is a way to understand how
translation_text.dn9:20.6: perception arises first and knowledge afterwards; that the arising of perception leads to the arising of knowledge.”
translation_text.dn9:21.1: “Sir, is perception a person’s self, or are perception and self different things?”
translation_text.dn9:21.2: “But Poṭṭhapāda, do you believe in a self?”
translation_text.dn9:21.3: “I believe in a solid self, sir, which is formed, made up of the four principal states, and consumes edible food.”
translation_text.dn9:21.4: “Suppose there were such a solid self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
translation_text.dn9:21.5: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
translation_text.dn9:21.6: So long as that solid self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
translation_text.dn9:21.7: That is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
translation_text.dn9:22.1: “Sir, I believe in a mind-made self which is whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.”
translation_text.dn9:22.2: “Suppose there were such a mind-made self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
translation_text.dn9:22.3: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
translation_text.dn9:22.4: So long as that mind-made self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
translation_text.dn9:22.5: That too is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
translation_text.dn9:23.1: “Sir, I believe in a formless self which is made of perception.”
translation_text.dn9:23.2: “Suppose there were such a formless self, Poṭṭhapāda. In that case, perception would be one thing, the self another.
translation_text.dn9:23.3: Here is another way to understand how perception and self are different things.
translation_text.dn9:23.4: So long as that formless self remains, still some perceptions arise in a person and others cease.
translation_text.dn9:23.5: That too is a way to understand how perception and self are different things.”
translation_text.dn9:24.1: “But, sir, am I able to know whether
translation_text.dn9:24.2: perception is a person’s self, or whether perception and self are different things?”
translation_text.dn9:24.3: “It’s hard for you to understand this, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition.”
translation_text.dn9:25.3: then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.dn9:25.4: “This has not been declared by me, Poṭṭhapāda.”
translation_text.dn9:26.1: “Then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.dn9:26.2: “This too has not been declared by me.”
translation_text.dn9:27.1: “Then what do you make of this: ‘The cosmos is finite …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.3: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.4: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.5: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.6: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.7: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …
translation_text.dn9:27.8: ‘A Realized One neither still exists nor no longer exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.dn9:27.9: “This too has not been declared by me.”
translation_text.dn9:28.1: “Why haven’t these things been declared by the Buddha?”
translation_text.dn9:28.2: “Because they’re not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn9:28.3: That’s why I haven’t declared them.”
translation_text.dn9:29.1: “Then what has been declared by the Buddha?”
translation_text.dn9:29.2: “I have declared this: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.”
translation_text.dn9:30.1: “Why have these things been declared by the Buddha?”
translation_text.dn9:30.2: “Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn9:30.3: That’s why I have declared them.”
translation_text.dn9:30.4: “That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!
translation_text.dn9:30.5: Please, sir, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.dn9:30.6: Then the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.dn9:31.1: Soon after the Buddha left, those wanderers beset Poṭṭhapāda on all sides with sneering and jeering.
translation_text.dn9:31.2: “No matter what the ascetic Gotama says, Poṭṭhapāda agrees with him:
translation_text.dn9:31.3: ‘That’s so true, Blessed One! That’s so true, Holy One!’
translation_text.dn9:31.4: We understand that the ascetic Gotama didn’t give any categorical teaching at all regarding whether the cosmos is eternal and so on.”
translation_text.dn9:31.6: When they said this, Poṭṭhapāda said to them,
translation_text.dn9:31.7: “I too understand that the ascetic Gotama didn’t give any categorical teaching at all regarding whether the cosmos is eternal and so on.
translation_text.dn9:31.10: Nevertheless, the practice that he describes is true, real, and accurate. It is the regularity of natural principles, the surety of natural principles.
translation_text.dn9:31.11: So how on earth could a sensible person such as I not agree that what was well spoken by the ascetic Gotama was in fact well spoken?”
translation_text.dn9:32.1: Then after two or three days had passed, Citta Hatthisāriputta and Poṭṭhapāda went to see the Buddha. Citta Hatthisāriputta bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn9:32.2: But the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda exchanged greetings with the Buddha, and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn9:32.3: Poṭṭhapāda told the Buddha what had happened after he left. The Buddha said:
translation_text.dn9:33.1: “All those wanderers, Poṭṭhapāda, are blind and sightless.
translation_text.dn9:33.2: You are the only one whose eyes are clear.
translation_text.dn9:33.3: For I have taught and pointed out teachings that are categorical
translation_text.dn9:33.4: and also teachings that are not categorical.
translation_text.dn9:33.5: And what teachings have I taught and pointed out as not categorical?
translation_text.dn9:33.10: ‘The soul is the same thing as the body’ …
translation_text.dn9:33.11: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another’ …
translation_text.dn9:33.12: ‘A realized one still exists after death’ …
translation_text.dn9:33.13: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’ …
translation_text.dn9:33.14: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’ …
translation_text.dn9:33.15: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’
translation_text.dn9:33.16: And why have I taught and pointed out such teachings as not categorical?
translation_text.dn9:33.17: Because those things aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn9:33.18: That’s why I have taught and pointed out such teachings as not categorical.
translation_text.dn9:33.20: And what teachings have I taught and pointed out as categorical?
translation_text.dn9:33.21: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.dn9:33.25: And why have I taught and pointed out such teachings as categorical?
translation_text.dn9:33.26: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn9:33.27: That’s why I have taught and pointed out such teachings as categorical.
translation_text.dn9:34.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.dn9:34.2: ‘The self is perfectly happy and free of disease after death.’
translation_text.dn9:34.3: I go up to them and say,
translation_text.dn9:34.4: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.dn9:34.8: ‘But do you meditate knowing and seeing a perfectly happy world?’
translation_text.dn9:34.11: ‘But have you perceived a perfectly happy self for a single day or night, or even half a day or night?’
translation_text.dn9:34.15: a path and a practice to realize a perfectly happy world?’
translation_text.dn9:34.18: ‘But have you ever heard the voice of the deities reborn in a perfectly happy world saying,
translation_text.dn9:34.19: “Practice well, good fellows, practice directly so as to realize a perfectly happy world.
translation_text.dn9:34.20: For this is how we practiced, and we were reborn in a perfectly happy world”?’
translation_text.dn9:34.23: This being so, doesn’t what they say turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:35.1: “Suppose, Poṭṭhapāda, a man were to say:
translation_text.dn9:35.2: ‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her that I desire!’
translation_text.dn9:35.4: ‘Worthy man, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial?’
translation_text.dn9:35.7: ‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or dingy? What village, town, or city she comes from?’
translation_text.dn9:35.10: ‘Worthy man, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’
translation_text.dn9:35.13: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:36.1: “In the same way, the ascetics and brahmins who have that doctrine and view …
translation_text.dn9:36.22: Doesn’t what they say turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:37.1: “Suppose a man was to build a ladder at the crossroads for climbing up to a stilt longhouse.
translation_text.dn9:37.3: ‘Worthy man, that stilt longhouse that you’re building a ladder for—do you know whether it’s to the north, south, east, or west? Or whether it’s tall or short or medium?’
translation_text.dn9:37.6: ‘Worthy man, are you building a ladder for a longhouse that you’ve never even known or seen?’
translation_text.dn9:37.9: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:38.1: “In the same way, the ascetics and brahmins who have those various doctrines and views …
translation_text.dn9:38.21: Doesn’t what they say turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:39.1: “Poṭṭhapāda, there are these three kinds of incarnation:
translation_text.dn9:39.2: a solid incarnation, a mind-made incarnation, and a formless incarnation.
translation_text.dn9:39.3: And what is a solid incarnation?
translation_text.dn9:39.4: It is formed, made up of the four principal states, and consumes edible food.
translation_text.dn9:39.6: It is formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
translation_text.dn9:39.8: It is formless, made of perception.
translation_text.dn9:40.1: I teach the Dhamma for the giving up of reincarnation in these three kinds of incarnation.
translation_text.dn9:40.2: ‘When you practice accordingly, corrupting qualities will be given up in you and cleansing qualities will grow. You’ll enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with your own insight in this very life.’
translation_text.dn9:40.4: ‘Corrupting qualities will be given up and cleansing qualities will grow. One will enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with one’s own insight in this very life. But such a life is suffering.’
translation_text.dn9:40.5: But you should not see it like this.
translation_text.dn9:40.6: Corrupting qualities will be given up and cleansing qualities will grow. One will enter and remain in the fullness and abundance of wisdom, having realized it with one’s own insight in this very life. And there will be only joy and happiness, tranquility, mindfulness and awareness. Such a life is blissful.
translation_text.dn9:43.1: Poṭṭhapāda, if others should ask us,
translation_text.dn9:43.2: ‘But reverends, what is that solid incarnation for the giving up of which you teach?’ We’d answer like this,
translation_text.dn9:44.2: ‘But reverends, what is that mind-made incarnation?’ We’d answer like this,
translation_text.dn9:45.2: ‘But reverends, what is that formless incarnation?’ We’d answer like this,
translation_text.dn9:45.6: This being so, doesn’t that statement turn out to have a demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:46.1: “Suppose a man were to build a ladder for climbing up to a stilt longhouse right underneath that longhouse.
translation_text.dn9:46.3: ‘Worthy man, that stilt longhouse that you’re building a ladder for—do you know whether it’s to the north, south, east, or west? Or whether it’s tall or short or medium?’
translation_text.dn9:46.5: ‘This is that stilt longhouse for which I’m building a ladder, right underneath it.’
translation_text.dn9:46.7: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have a demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.dn9:48.1: When the Buddha had spoken, Citta Hatthisāriputta said,
translation_text.dn9:48.2: “Sir, when reincarnated in a solid incarnation, are the mind-made and formless incarnations fictitious,
translation_text.dn9:48.3: and only the solid incarnation real?
translation_text.dn9:48.4: When reincarnated in a mind-made incarnation, are the solid and formless incarnations fictitious,
translation_text.dn9:48.5: and only the mind-made incarnation real?
translation_text.dn9:48.6: When reincarnated in a formless incarnation, are the solid and mind-made incarnations fictitious,
translation_text.dn9:48.7: and only the formless incarnation real?”
translation_text.dn9:49.1: “When reincarnated in a solid incarnation, it’s not referred to as a mind-made or formless incarnation,
translation_text.dn9:49.3: When reincarnated in a mind-made incarnation, it’s not referred to as a solid or formless incarnation,
translation_text.dn9:49.5: When reincarnated in a formless incarnation, it’s not referred to as a solid or mind-made incarnation,
translation_text.dn9:49.7: Citta, suppose they were to ask you,
translation_text.dn9:49.9: Will you exist in the future?
translation_text.dn9:49.12: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
translation_text.dn9:49.18: I will exist in the future.
translation_text.dn9:50.1: “But Citta, suppose they were to ask you,
translation_text.dn9:50.2: ‘Is the reincarnation you had in the past your only real one, and those of the future and present fictitious?
translation_text.dn9:50.3: Is the reincarnation you will have in the future your only real one, and those of the past and present fictitious?
translation_text.dn9:50.4: Is the reincarnation you have now your only real one, and those of the past and future fictitious?’
translation_text.dn9:50.6: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,
translation_text.dn9:50.11: ‘The reincarnation I had in the past was real at that time, and those of the future and present fictitious.
translation_text.dn9:50.12: The reincarnation I will have in the future will be real at the time, and those of the past and present fictitious.
translation_text.dn9:50.13: The reincarnation I have now is real at this time, and those of the past and future fictitious.’
translation_text.dn9:51.1: “In the same way, while in any one of the three reincarnations, it’s not referred to as the other two, only under its own name.
translation_text.dn9:52.1: From a cow comes milk, from milk comes curds, from curds come butter, from butter comes ghee, and from ghee comes cream of ghee. And the cream of ghee is said to be the best of these.
translation_text.dn9:52.2: While it’s milk, it’s not referred to as curds, butter, ghee, or cream of ghee.
translation_text.dn9:52.3: It’s only referred to as milk.
translation_text.dn9:52.7: or cream of ghee, it’s not referred to as anything else,
translation_text.dn9:53.1: In the same way, while in any one of the three reincarnations, it’s not referred to as the other two, only under its own name.
translation_text.dn9:53.5: These are the world’s common usages, definitions, expressions, and descriptions, which the Realized One uses to communicate without getting stuck on them.”
translation_text.dn9:54.1: When he had spoken, the wanderer Poṭṭhapāda said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn9:54.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn9:54.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn9:54.5: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
translation_text.dn9:55.1: But Citta Hatthisāriputta said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn9:55.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn9:55.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn9:55.5: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
translation_text.dn9:56.1: And Citta Hatthisāriputta received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.dn9:56.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Citta Hatthisāriputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn9:56.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.dn9:56.4: And Venerable Citta Hatthisāriputta became one of the perfected.
